actions-list.actionItem: The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for approximately 6:30 P.M. today.

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H. Res. 311.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. McCaul moved to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution. H. Res. 311 — "Encouraging the expansion and strengthening of the Abraham Accords to urge other nations to normalize relations with Israel and ensure that existing agreements reap tangible security and economic benefits for the citizens of those countries and all peoples in the region."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H. Res. 90.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. McCaul moved to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution, as amended. H. Res. 90 — "Demanding that the Government of the People's Republic of China and the Communist Party of China immediately release Mark Swidan."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1339.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Latta moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1339 — "To require the Federal Communications Commission to review certain rules of the Commission and develop recommendations for rule changes to promote precision agriculture, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1343.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Latta moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1343 — "To codify the Institute for Telecommunication Sciences and to direct the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information to establish an initiative to support the development of emergency communication and tracking technologies, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1353.
Considered under suspension of the rules. H.R. 1353 — "To direct the Federal Communications Commission to issue rules for the provision of emergency connectivity service, and for other purposes."

Mr. Latta moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 1353 — "To direct the Federal Communications Commission to issue rules for the provision of emergency connectivity service, and for other purposes."
The Speaker announced that votes on suspensions, if ordered, will be postponed until a time to be announced.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of April 25.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches.
The Chair designated Mr. Thompson of PA to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of April 25.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for approximately 2:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 2:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Anthony D'Esposito to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
